Generally what you have to do, if you get something from somebody else you have to be, â€œOh, I have to clone this thing because I got this from somebody else.â€ So, worrying about aliasing or mutating somebody elseâ€™s code or having to defensively clone something, thatâ€™s something that ClojureScript programmers donâ€™t do. And once you get that, there are a lot of, the types of programs you might write get dramatically simpler because itâ€™s just not something youâ€™re concerned about. So, if I would say anything, ClojureScript tries to deliver on the convenience, at least at the linguistic level, that JavaScript offers. But it tries to replace all the places where JavaScript is sort of fast and loose about mutation. It tries to add a little bit more discipline to that. CHUCK:Â  When it compiles, it just ignores the parts that implement mutability and things that we have on regular JavaScript objects? DAVID:Â  Thatâ€™s not true. We do lots of crazy tricks around cloning arrays and sharing structure between different immutable values as much as possible, and only mutating the part thatâ€™s changing. And we expose that, those facilities, to users because there are programs where you might care, where you need it. And also, itâ€™s actually super important for inter-op, right? If I want to talk to the canvas tag, I have to set properties on the canvas tags. So, I need access to mutation. But the idea is that when youâ€™re writing a big program, the places where you use mutation, itâ€™s quite small whereas in the typical JavaScript program, mutationâ€™s happening everywhere. JAMISON:Â  So, I feel like thatâ€™s a really concise definition of immutability. Itâ€™s easier to test.â€ And thereâ€™s a lot, the way that components interact or different parts of your program interact, there are less variables at play. So, thatâ€™s the reason people got excited about Clojure. MERRICK: Sure. It seems like the programming paradigm of mutability and imperative code is so ingrained that these platforms are embracing them wholesale. It really explained the architecture behind it. And I sort of got an epiphany. It was like because React is based on diffing and itâ€™s not based on observation, I really saw an opportunity for immutable data structures to basically make Reactâ€™s diffing process much faster. Because of immutable data, the differing algorithm just has to do less work. And that was just a hunch. And then he had had [inaudible]. And Om was an experiment to see, just for fun, Iâ€™m going to see if this is any faster. And then it was shocking how much faster it was. And not only just how much faster, I didnâ€™t really have to do that much work. And it was just way more efficient than the types of, I would say when you first set out to write a JavaScript program, people say, â€œOptimization is the root of all evil.â€ And thatâ€™s true because youâ€™re going to get sidetracked when youâ€™re optimizing. But often when you write a JavaScript program and youâ€™re just doing the naÃ¯ve way and then it performs really, really badly. And what was fun about React and Om was it was really naÃ¯ve. I didnâ€™t spend that much time optimizing it. It was cool to see that it was just without much work on my part, significantly faster. JAMISON:Â  So, I know youâ€™ve covered it in detail in other places. There is a podcast you did with the thoughtbot people where you talked a lot about the internals and how specifically ClojureScript and Om make React faster. But do you want to give a quick explanation of it? DAVID:Â  Yes. So, the way that React works, actually the React guys have done a great job in making it fast. But basically, React takes, if you look at React it basically takes JavaScript objects as parameters. And in order to do the diffing, what they have to do is they have to traverse whatever value you give them because thereâ€™s no efficient way to know that something has been mutated unless of course you can do something similar to this with observation. And weâ€™ll get back to why observation doesnâ€™t give you all the properties that you want. But without explicit observation that works on all JavaScript objects you might be interested in, you have to just walk the entire JavaScript object to figure out what changed between these two frames. And with immutable data structures you donâ€™t have to do this. And this is just simply because if two immutable values donâ€™t change, theyâ€™re going to basically point at the same thing in memory. Thatâ€™s really the key idea here. Whereas in JavaScript you canâ€™t detect it, in ClojureScript you can. Because if something is different, you know itâ€™s different. If something is the same, you donâ€™t need to look at it. This is just based on pointers. In JavaScript if you point to some location in memory and somebody changes something about that thing in memory, the pointer doesnâ€™t tell you that itâ€™s different. Does that make sense? MERRICK:Â  Sure. DAVID:Â  But in ClojureScript, if the pointers change in memory, it canâ€™t possibly be the same thing so you know to check. But if the pointers are the same, you do not need to look at the contents of the thing thatâ€™s being pointed at. JAMISON:Â  So, maybe another higher level way to say it is that in ClojureScript, equality is based on the values that are in an object, not where it points to in memory. If two objects are equal in ClojureScript it means they contain the same values so you donâ€™t have to descend down into them to check if their sub-properties are equal or not, right? DAVID:Â  Thatâ€™s exactly correct. Itâ€™s impossible to change something nested inside of a value and not break the pointer. Thatâ€™s exactly right. If you try to update something deeply nested in the thing, youâ€™re going to change all the pointers. All the pointers must change. MERRICK:Â  So, it seems like this would become a memory problem really quickly, right? AJ:Â  Yeah, thatâ€™s what I was thinking. MERRICK:Â  But I know that FRP people have interesting strategies for abstracting these things with deltas and stuff. How does ClojureScript store these kinds of data structures? DAVID:Â  The idea is very, very simple. You want to represent an array. But instead of having the array be represented as one huge array, which of course is impossible to update efficiently in a mutable way, you can instead organize your array-like thing in terms of trees of arrays. You would have an array at the root. Say it has four slots. And so, if you want to get to the first thing, you descend down the first slot to the next array that has four slots in it. And then you got to descend again. And of course this sounds like, â€œOh that works,â€ and it turns out if you just pick a really good branching factor, itâ€™s pretty wild what you can do. So, the branching factor in ClojureScript is 32. And say you have to descend 32 of these arrays, you go to depth seven, right? If your branching factor is 32, thatâ€™s 34 billion items which I think is, youâ€™re talking 60 or 70 gigs of RAM. Thatâ€™s pretty wild. So, you only have to hop down seven arrays to get to the thing you want. And that size is far bigger than anything youâ€™re going to want to put in the browser. And so, whatâ€™s really cool is that imagine you want to update something that has 32 billion items in it. How many things do you have to update to update one value? You just have to replace seven arrays. Thatâ€™s pretty crazy. In order to update any value in something that large, youâ€™re only going to have to pay for seven array updates. And as it turns out, JavaScript is now, for arrays that are small like this, cloning is really, really, really fast. If you do an Array.prototype.slice on an array like this, itâ€™s a very cheap operation. MERRICK:Â  So, you said that ClojureScript compiles to these plain old JavaScript data structures. ClojureScript will often produce code you would never want to write by hand and stuff that weâ€™ve benchmarked on V8 and JavaScriptCore and SpiderMonkey. And we can do these patterns that you would never want to do. For example, all of our fastest data structures use this 32 array branching factor trick. We have a really, really fast hash map. They donâ€™t have the hooks that you need if you want to use immutable data structures. And it works great and it ends up being pretty fast. JAMISON:Â  And that snapshot stuff is more a feature of Om than ClojureScript or React specifically, right? DAVID:Â  The snapshot feature is really, comes straight from the immutable data structures. And we happen to provide them out of the box. I try to tell a lot of people the data structures that ClojureScript uses are basically ports of the ones that Rich Hickey, the inventor of Clojure, originally wrote in Java. We just ported them. Theyâ€™re amazingly well-designed and theyâ€™re ridiculously fast. Theyâ€™re fast in the JVM. Theyâ€™re fast on modern JavaScript engines. So, what that means is that when you get a list in Scheme you canâ€™t provide a custom data type that looks and acts like a list. Youâ€™re stuck with a concrete type. So, the way that ClojureScript and Clojure is designed, if you want to create your own type and you want to magically work with all code that deals with lists, you can basically create a custom type that satisfies the list interface.
